title: Don't follow the president's lead: Chanting 'lock him up' isn't OK.
text:
At a certain point, we have to create a standard for civility, and President Trump shouldn't be the one setting it.

Of all of President Donald Trump’s transgressions and trespasses, none has been more un-American than his battle cry of “lock her up,” in reference to Hillary Clinton. Simply put, we do not imprison our opponents in this country. Leave that to Russia's Vladimir Putin and other despots. We don’t do this whether she’s a Democrat or he’s a Republican. But that didn’t stop some loud fans at Game 5 of the World Series from attempting to rival the president for the title of “ugliest American,” when they chanted, “Lock him up!” between the third and fourth innings.

The morning after, Joe Scarborough, host of MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” called out the crowd’s behavior as “just un-American.” He continued, “It started with Donald Trump. In fact, he's made it a centerpiece of his campaign rallies. … We are Americans, and we do not do that. We do not want the world hearing us chant, 'Lock him up,' to this president or to any president."

Agreed. And I’m doubling down with his co-host Mika Brzezinski, who pressed the point: "We find it sickening when it happens at his rallies.”

That chant is equally sickening when it happens during a nationally televised baseball game. We are not a rogue nation that “locks up” its politicians.

Is it OK to heckle a president?

But yes, there’s a distinction, as historian Heather Cox Richardson reminds us: “Presidents get heckled; it goes with the turf. This is not the same thing as presidents heckling individuals, which carries with it the weight of the government being used against people the leaders don't like.”

No sooner had Brzezinski and Scarborough finished, the debate took off on Twitter, with the co-hosts taken to the woodshed.

One Twitter user asserted: “It is a patriotic act, a right under the Constitution to free speech and assembly. It’s as patriotic as chanting ‘Lock her up’ #ImpeachTrump #WeThePeople”

President Donald Trump attends the fifth game of the World Series on Oct. 27, 2019. (Photo: Chris Kleponis/Pool)

Let’s be clear, the MSNBC hosts didn’t say that the crowd had no right to their chant or that their freedom of expression should be limited. No, not at all. In an Instagram post, Brezinski replied: "Remember @repcummings famous words, 'We are better than this'! #Morningjoe"

Another set of critiques went far afield, conflating the condemnation of “Lock him up!” with what I’ll call the “Bonus Constitutional Amendment," our right to boo those with whom we disagree. Make no mistake: Booing is as American as baseball or apple pie.

I'm all for civility: But what if our fellow citizens express contemptible views?

For instance, it’s not unusual for presidents to be booed at baseball games. In a tweet, historian Kevin Kruse reminded us, “And other presidents have been booed at baseball games, in case everyone suddenly forgot. If I'm remembering correctly, Obama was booed at the All-Star Game in 2009, and GWBush was booed at a Nationals game in 2008, and GHWBush was famously booed at the 1992 All-Star Game”

“Boo” all you want; it’s how we voice disapproval. The civility police will not jail you for its use.

Voicing their discontent through boos

Another person responded: "Nope, nope, nope Joe. This dude and his administration have deeply damaged our constitution, world standing, the planet, our laws, women, children, our military, poor folks, middle class folks, poc, EVERYONE. He should be booed every minute of every day forever."

Then came the busload of tweeters who ran back and forth over Brzezinski and Scarborough, devising a laundry list of mitigating circumstances why the fans were right to chant, “Lock him up.” Many of their tweets focused on the legitimacy of the Trump presidency. They are right that Trump doesn’t look like a president, doesn’t talk like a president and doesn’t act like a president. Yes, there’s every reason — and still a few more — to question his legitimacy.

Still another person tweeted: “Problem is, Trump isn't a president. I mean, technically he is, but in every other regard, he isn't. He needs to be called out with any chant his opposition can come up with, as often as possible.”

OK, then, impeach the guy. Right, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is on that already.

Finally, Twitter brought its laser-like focus to bear on me, The Civilist, and others like me.

One user said: "Right on cue, here's the civility police, telling everyone to be nice to the man locking up kids in cages and abandoning key allies to genocide. I look forward to your similar tongue clucking about the President encouraging inevitable 'lock him/her up' chants at his next rally."

That tweet was liked nearly 3,000 times.

A refuge for cruelty: Fight on the side of civility in America’s social media civil war

No one’s saying — least of all Mika, Joe or me — that Americans should be “nice to the man locking up kids in cages and abandoning key allies to genocide.” What I am strongly suggesting is: Don’t play dirty ball like Donald Trump.

Civility is a two-way street: To subvert American values as the president does nearly every day, to threaten to “lock her up,” to seek dirt on a rival candidate from a foreign power — demands that we stand up for our democratic values of respect and due process and, should it come to it, an impeachment trial in the Senate.

That’s the American way.
